Package fr.sorbonne_u.components.cyphy.examples.molene

Molene example in a cyber-physical component model based on BCM.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    CVM
    The class CVM deploys the Molene example on a single JVM for execution.
    DistributedCVM
    The class DistributedCVM deploys the Molene example as a multi-JVM execution using currently three JVMs.

Package fr.sorbonne_u.components.cyphy.examples.molene Description

Molene example in a cyber-physical component model based on BCM.

Licence

Copyright Jacques Malenfant, Sorbonne Universite.

Jacques.Malenfant@lip6.fr

This software is a computer program whose purpose is to provide an example for the extension of the BCM component model that aims to define a components tailored for cyber-physical control systems (CPCS) for Java.

This software is governed by the CeCILL-C license under French law and abiding by the rules of distribution of free software. You can use, modify and/ or redistribute the software under the terms of the CeCILL-C license as circulated by CEA, CNRS and INRIA at the following URL http://www.cecill.info.

As a counterpart to the access to the source code and rights to copy, modify and redistribute granted by the license, users are provided only with a limited warranty and the software's author, the holder of the economic rights, and the successive licensors have only limited liability.

In this respect, the user's attention is drawn to the risks associated with loading, using, modifying and/or developing or reproducing the software by the user in light of its specific status of free software, that may mean that it is complicated to manipulate, and that also therefore means that it is reserved for developers and experienced professionals having in-depth computer knowledge. Users are therefore encouraged to load and test the software's suitability as regards their requirements in conditions enabling the security of their systems and/or data to be ensured and, more generally, to use and operate it in the same conditions as regards security.

The fact that you are presently reading this means that you have had knowledge of the CeCILL-C license and that you accept its terms.

The Molene example is inspired by a system that was developed by Maria-Teresa Segarra as part of her thesis at IRISA (Rennes). Basically, the goal was to perform run time adaptation to get the best possible data transfer rate over a WiFi network. Two entities exchange large data, one is on a PC running on battery, the other is on a server. When the WiFi bandwidth is low, better data transfer rates can be obtained by first compressing the data, transmit the compressed data and then uncompress upon reception. However, compressing and uncompressing consume computational resources, hence energy, which is limited on the PC. Therefore, the adaptation avoids compression when the bandwidth is high to save battery life.

Cyber-physical components here are components with DEVS simulation models attached to them to provide for both a specification of their cyber-physical behaviour and also to be used to validate and verify this specification. On a longer term, SIL models would also be used to debug, test, verify and validate the software. Here, a new Java library for DEVS simulation models is used, and the models for the Molene example have already been developed as an example of this library. The present package only includes the component part of the example, with the integration of models within them.
